utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: What brings you in?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Well, I've had this cough but the biggest issue is that I've been really short of breath.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, um, when did the cough start?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I would say about 3 days ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Three days ago, OK, and uh, around that time did you also start feeling short of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, the shortness of breath has come on, I don't know within the last day or so. It's come on after that, the cough started first.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and the cough, is it a dry cough or is it a wet cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Well, I've been bringing up some yellowish green, kind of like phlegm, so um I guess a wet cough.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, so yeah, yellowish green you said.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any blood in the sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I haven't noticed any blood.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how much sputum are you coughing up each time? Like is it kind of the size of your fingertip or does it fill your whole palm?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, yeah, probably more like the size of like a thumb tip.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK um, and do you notice any, like pus or froth in the sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Nothing like that I noticed.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and if you were to describe the sound of your cough, does it sound like it's barky or like a hacking cough?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I don't know, I guess hacking.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Alright, and do you hear any wheezing at all?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, well, maybe I guess when I'm really short of breath, yeah, wheezing, yeah.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and the shortness of breath, how severe is it? 1 to 10, 10 being the worst?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Maybe a 7?

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: At seven OK, are you having issues sleeping because of your shortness of breath?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, well I can't tell if it's that or the cough. I mean between those two things it's been definitely interrupting my sleep.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you find there are any triggers to your coughing like like um, a particular time of the day? Triggers like you know pollen or things in your environment like pets?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No the cough has been kind of going on all day. Um, right when I get up in the morning and goes on all night, it's been getting worse to these last few days.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK yeah, um yeah, that doesn't sound great in terms of your shortness of breath. Do you find that certain positions make it worse? Or like exerting yourself makes it worse?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, not really.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have you ever experienced anything like this in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And any other symptoms that you have along with your coughing and sputum?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: As soon as I breath, well, I just haven't felt good like, tired, kind of weakish.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK yeah um, along with your fatigue and feeling weak, have you experienced any dizziness or fainting spells?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No dizziness and I haven't fainted or anything like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any confusion or memory loss?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No concerns with my memory.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. And how about um, muscle aches or any sort of body aches?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Alright, yeah, maybe a bit, kind of, and weak.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, alright, so let's go back to your shortness of breath. Do you have any chest pain associated with that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and do you ever feel like your heart's racing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about changes to your bowel movements?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, those have been normal. I haven't had any diarrhea or constipation.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK and no blood in your stool?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I haven't noticed any blood, no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about abdominal pains?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh yeah, I don't know why, yeah, my belly's been a bit achy maybe.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about a sore throat?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, my throat felt OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good and have you experienced any loss of taste?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No loss of taste, but I've noticed, yeah, my smell has been kind of funny.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Your smell has been kind of funny, like you can't smell or do things smell differently than you expect them to?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, there was a candle on earlier today and I guess I couldn't really smell it, so I guess I haven't been able to smell.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Ok, do you have a runny nose or a blocked nose?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't had to blow my nose or anything.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any changes in your vision or hearing?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, that's been normal.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any discharge or pain in your eyes or ears?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, that's been OK.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then any changes to your urine?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't had any pain or anything like that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and are you otherwise healthy? Do you have any medical conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I have atrial fibrillation. And I do take Metoprolol for that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how long have you had A. fib?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It was like 4 years ago I think it was. It was having that like, felt like my heart was racing you were asking about earlier and they did an ECG and I was told I had atrial fibrillation. So yeah, I've been on a beta blocker for three years now.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, four years, and when was the last time you had an ECG?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, maybe just a couple of months ago. I think every time that I come in to see my family doctor, they they do one.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and the last time that it was done, was it normal?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, they said yeah. My heart rate's been around 80 beats per minute which is good and I haven't had any symptoms so things have been stable.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good. And then have you had any hospitalizations or surgeries in the past?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I had an inguinal hernia repair about 15 years ago.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, any complications from that?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um no.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and then besides the Metoprolol, are you on any other medications?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Oh yeah, I take a statin and baby aspirin.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and is that for the A. fib as well, the aspirin? Or is that just for other cardiovascular issues or some sort of preventative measure?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, I heard it was good for people who have atrial fibrillation so I started taking it.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK. and let's revisit your medications at the end of today's session. I just want to make sure that you're on the medications and I just want to make sure you're on the right dose.  Does that sound good?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, certainly.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK great. And ok, so we talked about your past medical history and medications. We will talk a little bit about any allergies that you have, if you have any.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I think it's like a sulfa allergy. I received an antibiotic like that many years ago and had a rash.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK and have you had any reason to suspect that you may have taken any sulfas recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I haven't had any antibiotics so no, really no changes.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, good and are you up to date with all your immunizations?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I am yeah. I've received the Zoster vaccine for shingles and also the one for pneumonia.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good, good yeah, those two we definitely recommend if you're over 65. OK, and do you know of any family history of lung conditions or heart conditions?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I think my aunt had lung cancer but she smoked her entire life.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK and how about other cancers?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No other cancers.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And have you been in touch or do you think you've been in contact with any anyone sick recently?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Well, I visited my mother at a long term care facility just this past weekend, so I guess about just over a week ago I visited there.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and have there been any COVID outbreaks at the long term care?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, there has been, I thought I was like away from those areas but I have heard about outbreaks there.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK and any travel history?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No travel.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: And do you smoke?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day, but I quit about, uh, about five years ago. I know four years ago it was when I found out I had atrial fibrillation. I quit.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK, well that's good. Good for you for quitting. How about marijuana?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, I don't smoke it, but I'll use some edibles I buy from the Ontario stores a couple of times per week. Just the CBD stuff.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: The CBD stuff OK. And how many milligrams?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I'm not sure, I know it's their lowest dose though.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, OK if it's lowest dose, it might be 2.5 milligrams.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Sounds familiar.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK good. Is there a particular reason you take these CBD edibles?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: It helps me sleep.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, if it's specifically to help you sleep, we can actually try and see if there are other options for you. You know there are pills, like they are sleep aids. Or even things like melatonin that can help regulate your sleep so we can revisit other options for you if you're open to that as well.

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: OK for sure. Yeah I will. Um, yeah we can talk about that later.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, that sounds good and do you do any other recreational drugs?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I do not.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, how about alcohol?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Uh, no, I don't drink anymore.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and did you used to drink before?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yes, I just stopped a few years ago,

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and what's your living situation like right now?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: I live in a house with my wife.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: In a house, OK. Any concerns for like old carpets, mold or asbestos in your house?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, we've renovated it over the years.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, good and I apologize, but I would like to clarify three more symptoms with you. Did you say you felt like you had a fever earlier?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, maybe I've been feeling a little hot, but it's been really more the cough and shortness of breath that's been bugging me.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, well we can take a temperature today just to make sure. Have you been feeling like you have night sweats or chills?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Um, not really. No, I haven't noticed that.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, and how about, um, any weight loss over the past few months?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, it's been been stable.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, alright good, so that brings us to the end. Do you have any questions or concerns that you would like to clarify before we end the interview?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: No, nothing today.  I was just really hoping to get, uh, whatever this is sorted out.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: Yeah, you know, um, right now it looks like, it sounds like it could be an upper respiratory viral illness, so that includes COVID.  So we will do a swab for you and then send it off to the lab for PCR results. In the meantime, because you have symptoms that overlap with COVID symptoms, we do encourage isolation for 14 days. Until your symptoms are gone, sorry,  until your symptoms are gone, even if they're gone, we do suggest isolating for 14 days just to make sure you're not a carrier or could spread COVID so we do encourage that, and that includes from your husband. If possible, we will get those results in a day or two. If they are positive, we will send your results to public health who will be in touch with you to do some contact tracing to see where you may have gotten it from. If it's not COVID, it could be other viral illnesses that are going around this time of year. And if your symptoms aren't getting better on their own, and there's reason to suspect you may have a bacterial infection or bacterial pneumonia, we will follow up with you and possibly prescribe antibiotics. How does that sound?

utterances.speaker: patient
utterances.text: Yeah, that sounds like a great plan.

utterances.speaker: doctor
utterances.text: OK, great so um, I will see you at the next appointment.

utterances.speaker: control
utterances.text: Add differential diagnosis
